awd_titl_txt: RUI: Next Generation RF Systems: Models and Simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
There is a wide range of beneficial and practical applications of accelerators and particle physics including medical diagnostic instrumentation, cancer therapy, monitoring of nuclear waste proliferation, computing, and many more. Optimizing an accelerator's operational parameters is a complex problem, yet critical to achieve robust performance and to increase the number of circulating particles. Computer models will be developed in this project to investigate the possible configurations, set specifications, and estimate the system performance. Algorithms will also be created to operate the accelerator as efficiently as possible, thus increasing the discovery potential in accelerator experiments.  Student participation is an integral part of this project. The students will benefit from participating in cutting-edge research and having access to SLAC National Accelerator Laboratory and the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in Geneva, Switzerland. They will develop scientific programming and modeling skills, learn how to create and validate simulations, conduct measurements, and be involved with operations of complex accelerator systems. All of these experiences will be a realistic introduction to graduate work, and/or work in advanced industry in one of the many areas in which accelerators play a key role.

Innovative developments in a broad range of subfields of accelerator physics and technology will be required to achieve the beam specifications for the next generation accelerators. There are two major objectives in this project. First, a general model of the interaction between the next generation radio frequency (RF) system and the particle beam dynamics will be generated, which can be applied to future particle colliders and light sources. Second, this general model will be validated through application to a particular particle accelerator. The simulations of the next generation RF and low level radio frequency (LLRF) systems will be developed as block systems in the computer program Simulink. The simulation defining parameters and the initial conditions will be set in Matlab. Multi-particle simulations will also be developed in Python. The validation of models developed during this project will be done using the Large Hadron Collider crab cavity system, located at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) in Geneva, Switzerland.   The validation process will involve conducting proof of principle simulations, investigating the LLRF-beam dynamics interaction, studying the LLRF implementation, examining detrimental effects, and developing control algorithms; thus expanding the deliverables of this project. This project will have a significant impact on advancing knowledge in accelerator physics. The knowledge and expertise developed will be directly applicable to future particle colliders and light sources.

por.por_cntn:
A major outcome of this project was the development of models and simulations to study the interaction of the particle beam with the accelerating system in particle colliders. There was a particular emphasis on the High Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC), a future particle collider at the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN), in Geneva, Switzerland. 

During this project, we developed an iterative and self-learning algorithm to adaptively change the accelerating system's operating point at every revolution of the particle beam (89 microseconds) at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). This algorithm significantly reduced klystron power requirements at the LHC, allowing for higher number of circulating particles. A klystron acts like a very powerful amplifier to provide the necessary power to accelerate the particles. 

Many other topics were investigated using the developed models and simulations, leading to various publications. This project has resulted in a peer-reviewed article on coupled-bunch instabilities in the HL-LHC [1]. These are instabilities due to the coupling of the motion of the particle clouds as they pass through accelerator structures. Another peer-reviewed article presented the iterative algorithm described above [2]. Finally, we prepared a peer-review article on transverse emittance growth due to crab cavity noise in the HL-LHC [3]. The transverse emittance is a measure of the size of the particle cloud perpendicularly to the direction of motion. This size can increase due to noise in the crab cavities, structures that rotate the particle beam right before and after the collision point. This last article also includes studies of a proposed cure for this emittance growth, as well as the results of the first crab cavity tests in the Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS).

Four CERN notes were also published during this project. The first presented a Machine Development session testing the proposed iterative algorithm described above [4]. The second presented results of a Machine Development session on how fast coupled-bunch instabilities grow in the LHC [5]. The third presented studies of the evolution of the transverse shape of the particle cloud due to crab cavity noise in the HL-LHC [6]. The fourth investigated the interaction of a proposed crab cavity feedback system with existing systems [7].

Undergraduate students are co-authors in three of these publications. The PI also participated in a CERN note defining the HL-LHC operational scenarios [8].

In addition, the project supported fifteen undergraduate students involved in accelerator physics, helped them develop research skills, and exposed them to world-renowned laboratory environments. Three of those students completed their senior project as part of this work. Two students are enrolled in graduate careers in physics and one student is enrolled in a graduate program in mathematics. 

Two separate groups of three students travelled with the PI to CERN in August 2016 and August 2017, and an additional student visited in September 2018. While at CERN, we conducted measurements at the LHC and the SPS. The PI and students presented their work in one-hour seminars at CERN in both 2016 and 2017. The project-supported students have also presented their work at the 2016, 2017, 2018, and 2019 College of Science and Mathematics Student Research Conferences at the California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo.

 

[1] P. Baudrenghien, T. Mastoridis, "Fundamental Cavity Impedance and Longitudinal Coupled-Bunch Instabilities at the High Luminosity Large Hadron Collider", Physical Review Accelerators and Beams 20, 011004, January 2017. 

[2] T. Mastoridis, P. Baudrenghien, J. Molendijk, "Cavity voltage phase modulation to reduce the high-luminosity Large Hadron Collider rf power requirements", Physical Review Accelerators and Beams 20, 101003, October 2017.

[3] T. Mastoridis, P. Baudrenghien, A. Daw, P. Nguyen, "Estimates of and a Cure for Transverse Emittance Growth due to RF Noise in the High Luminosity LHC Crab Cavities", prepared for submission to Physical Review Accelerators and Beams. 

[4] T. Mastoridis, P. Baudrenghien, J. Molendijk, H. Timko, "Cavity Voltage Phase Modulation MD", CERN-ACC-NOTE-2016-0061, October 2016.

[5] T. Mastoridis, P. Baudrenghien, E. Chapochnikova, J. Esteban-Muller, J. Molendijk, H. Timko, "Coupled-bunch instabilities due to fundamental cavity impedance", CERN-ACC-NOTE-2017-0009, February 2017. 

[6] P. Baudrenghien, T. Mastoridis, D. Wieker, S. Steeper, D. Tucker, "Transverse distribution evolution due to Crab Cavity noise in the HL-LHC", CERN-ACC-Note-2018-0042, June 2018.

[7] P. Baudrenghien, T. Mastoridis, B. Miller, "Crab Cavity RF Noise Feedback and Transverse Damper Interaction", CERN-ACC-NOTE-2019-0006, March 2019.

[8] E. Metral et. al., "Update of the HL-LHC operational scenarios for proton operation", CERN-ACC-NOTE-2018-0002, January 2018.
